Suresh Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Funding acquisition ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India Department of Chemical Engineering Indian Institute of Technology Bombay Mumbai India Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Oxidation state of the catalyst is important in determining the activity and selectivity of the catalyst in complex reaction networks. This effect is investigated here in the context of glycerol oxidation. An attempt is made to understand the effect of catalyst pre-treatment (oxidative and reductive) on Pd/Alumina for glycerol oxidation, and correlate the reaction performance with the oxidation state of Pd. Characterisation techniques such as XPS, TEM, CO pulse chemisorption have been used to understand the effect of pre-treatment on the oxidation state of the metal. The reduced catalyst was found to be more selective to C3 compounds than the oxidized catalyst. It is suggested that this difference in selectivity is due to differences in hydrogen peroxide formation over Pd and PdO phases, because of the role of peroxide in bringing about C–C scission. A novel procedure for parameter estimation based on reaction extents has been used to delineate the effect of pre-treatments on different reactions in the network. The results have been supported by systematic statistical analyses. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidation state Product yield Kinetic modelling Extent of reaction XPS Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the last few decades, biodiesel has been in great demand for fuel blending in most of the developed countries owing to strict environmental norms as well as governmental policies and incentives [1]. Glycerol, a major by-product from the transesterification reaction for biodiesel manufacturing, poses the problem of market oversaturation. This affects the economics of biodiesel production. Moreover, the separation and purification of crude glycerol is an expensive process, which small biodiesel manufacturers cannot afford. Converting glycerol to high-value chemicals is the only solution to this problem [2,3]. In this context, oxidation is one of the conversion routes that is being studied for almost four decades. Heterogeneous catalysis for glycerol oxidation has been extensively studied in the literature. However, achieving a good selectivity to the desired product has remained a challenge due to the complexity of the reaction network [4]. A good mechanistic understanding of catalyst activity and selectivity is necessary to engineer a commercially attractive process for glycerol oxidation. The present work is a step in this direction, and examines the effect of catalyst pre-treatment on its performance in glycerol oxidation under alkaline conditions, with an eye on carbon conversion efficiency. Along the way, we also develop some novel procedures for the kinetic investigation of complex reaction networks such as this, especially when the effect of treatments on individual reactions in a network needs to be understood. In oxidation reactions in general, there have been several reports on the effect of support materials on the performance of the catalyst. Examples are glucose oxidation [5], benzyl alcohol oxidation [6], ethanol oxidation [7] and cinnamaldehyde oxidation [8]. A recent study from our lab [9] reported the effect of various supports on the selectivity and activity of Pd metal in glycerol oxidation. Pd supported on activated carbon, alumina, silica and titania was used, and metal-support interaction was found to influence the catalyst performance. Using characterization tools like XPS, CO pulse chemisorption, etc., the support influence was identified as being caused mainly by the tendency of the support to shift the electron cloud either towards itself or towards the metal. The present work follows up on this work. We focus here mainly on how the rate and C3 selectivity are affected by oxidative/reductive pre-treatments of the catalyst. A decrease in the selectivity to C–C scission products improves the carbon economy and reduces CO2 emissions. Generally, a commercially obtained catalyst is assumed to be calcined or treated, and often used directly in reaction studies. On the other hand, catalysts are often treated under hydrogen flow up to the reduction temperature, to ensure that the catalyst is in completely reduced form. It is also usual in the laboratory testing and benchmarking of catalysts, for researchers to subject catalysts to a uniform pre-treatment for comparison. Such pre-treatments can have a major role in how the catalyst performs. In glycerol oxidation, although literature suggests that the oxidation state of the catalyst could be an important determinant of catalyst activity, a systematic study of the effect of pre-treatment has not been reported so far. Below, we briefly review the literature on similar catalytic reactions to highlight the importance of such studies. We have included only such studies as are relevant to the mechanism of glycerol oxidation (in which the oxygen does not directly adsorb on the catalyst, but is involved in the recycling of OH* radical [10]). An example is the work by Wang et al. [11], on the effect of oxidation state of Pd on hydrogen peroxide synthesis from gaseous hydrogen and oxygen. They used DFT calculations for two different configurations of Pd surface – Pd(111) and PdO(101) – because the latter configuration is preferentially obtained by oxidation of Pd(111). They concluded that water forms as a major product over Pd(111) surface while PdO(101) surface is favourable for higher yields of H2O2. The relevance of this study to our work is that in glycerol oxidation, H2O2 is recognised as having a role in C–C scission, and it would therefore be desirable to minimize its formation or maximize its decomposition rate (in contrast to the objective of Wang et al. [11], which was to improve the yield of H2O2). Metal-support interaction (MSI) can also influence or alter the oxidation states of the catalytically active metal, especially when the latter is supported on a metal oxide support. While MSI is a much-studied subject, most of the literature in this context is on gas-phase reactions, such as methane combustion, carbon monoxide oxidation, NOx reduction, etc., finding applications mostly in automobile catalytic converters [12–15]. As for the liquid phase oxidation, in the earlier work carried out in our lab by Namdeo et al. [9], the effect of different supports on Pd-catalyzed glycerol oxidation was studied. It was found that the influence of the support on activity and selectivity was significant. These results were explained using results from XPS analyses which showed a negative shift in binding energy for zero valent Palladium (Pd0) due to its interaction with metal oxide supports (i.e., alumina, titania, and silica), which correlated with a reduced activity of the catalyst and higher extent of C–C scission. Such a shift was not seen for (the fairly neutral) carbon support. Among the metal oxide supports, alumina supported Pd showed the highest activity. In the present work, an attempt is made to study the effect of oxidation state of Pd on activity as well as selectivity of glycerol oxidation reaction. Following on from the work of Namdeo et al. [9], Pd/Al2O3 is used for this study. To the best of our knowledge, such a study is carried out for the first time for liquid phase glycerol oxidation wherein oxidation state of active metal is correlated with the reaction performance. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst and pre-treatment methods Palladium supported on alumina (Pd/Al2O3, 5 % metal loading) was obtained from Vineeth Chemicals (Mumbai, India). The as-obtained catalyst was crushed using a mortar and pestle to reduce the particle size. The following pre-treatments were given to this catalyst in the TPDRO instrument (Make: Thermo Scientific; Model 1100): 1) Oxidation of catalyst was done using 5 % O2 in He (Med Gas & Equipment, India) with temperature ramped at the rate of 10 °C/min up to 600 °C, followed by a hold at the final temperature for 90 min, 2) Reduction of catalyst was done using 5 % H2 in Ar (Med Gas & Equipment, India) with the same temperature program as above. 3) A third pre-treatment was given with inert gas (Argon or Helium) with a similar temperature program in order to get rid of any adsorbed impurities on the as-obtained catalyst. The final temperature of 600 °C for the above pre-treatments was chosen based on the TGA-DSC profiles (see Figure S-1 in Supplementary material) which showed that PdO decomposes to Pd at temperatures close to 800 ºC even in an oxygen atmosphere. The TPDRO (Temperature-programmed Desorption/Reduction/Oxidation) instrument was also used to obtain Temperature-programmed reduction- (TPR) and oxidation- (TPO) profiles, in order to identify reduction and oxidation temperatures of the catalytic material. TPR/TPO were performed by flowing the reducing gas (5 % H2 mixed in Argon) or oxidizing gas (5 % O2 mixed in Helium) through a small bed of catalyst (about 100 mg) packed between plugs of quartz wool. The temperature was again ramped at 10 °C/min up to 600 ºC and held for 90 min at the final temperature. 2.2 Reaction studies A batch autoclave of 100 mL volume equipped with temperature and agitation speed control and a pressure gauge (shown in Fig. 1 ) was used for the oxidation reaction. Glycerol was obtained from Merck. 99.9 % pure oxygen obtained from Med Gas & Equipment (Mumbai, India) was used for oxidation. 0.6 M aqueous solution (60 mL) of glycerol was prepared in ultrapure water. NaOH (97 % purity, Merck) was added such that NaOH to glycerol molar ratio is 4. The catalyst Pd/Al2O3 was added such that the molar ratio of glycerol to active metal was 1000. These conditions are the same as those used in the study by Namdeo et al. [9]. The reactant mixture was initially stirred at 100 RPM under nitrogen atmosphere and heated up to the required temperature (60 °C). After attaining the required temperature, the nitrogen was replaced with oxygen and pressurized to 6 kg cm−2, and the stirring speed increased to 800 RPM. This stirring speed was chosen so as to eliminate all external transport resistances, based on the mass transfer studies reported by Namdeo et al. [16,17] for the same reactor setup. Sampling of product from the batch reactor was done at intervals. The samples were filtered through a 0.2-micron syringe filter and analyzed by HPLC as reported in [9]. The sample is highly alkaline, and hence, cannot be injected directly into the column. Thus, it was neutralized with a dilute solution of H2SO4 before injecting into HPLC. 2.2.1 Product analysis Oxidation of glycerol (GLY) in an alkaline medium over Pd-based catalysts yields a product mixture containing C3 compounds – Glyceric acid (GA) and Tartronic acid (TA), C2 compounds – Glycolic acid (GLYCA) and Oxalic acid (OA), and C1 compounds – Formic acid (FA) and CO2. These (except for CO2) were measured using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC; Make: Waters Corporation) equipped with an Aminex column, a binary pump (Model: Waters 1525 Binary HPLC Pump), UV detector (Model: Waters 2487 Dual λ Absorbance Detector), and RI detector (Model: Waters 2414 Refractive Index Detector). A micro-guard cartridge was connected upstream of the column to prevent particulates or fouling agents from entering the system. Any CO2 produced by reaction remains dissolved in the alkaline liquid medium, as carbonate. The method for analysis is reported in detail elsewhere [9]. UV detector was used to measure the concentrations of the above-mentioned products while RI detector was used to measure glycerol concentration. A 20-µL volume sample was injected for each analysis. Calibration plots were prepared for every component to be detected, using calibration standards of glycerol (98 %), dihydroxyacetone (98 %), formic acid, glycolic acid (70 % in water), and oxalic acid (98 %), obtained from Merck India. Tartronic acid (97 %) and glyceric acid calcium salt dihydrate (99 %) were obtained from Sigma Aldrich. Signal corresponding to peak height (in case of UV detector) and/or area under the curve (in case of RI detector) obtained using the Breeze software (provided by Waters Corporation) was plotted against the known concentration of the component to obtain calibration plots. The experimental results are presented graphically in the form of concentration-time profiles and/or yield-conversion profiles, wherever applicable. The product yield and conversion used in this work are defined below: Y i e l d o f p r o d u c t A ( Y A ) = m o l e s o f p r o d u c t A f o r m e d ( I n i t i a l − F i n a l ) m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l × m o l e s o f c a r b o n a t o m s p e r m o l e o f p r o d u c t A m o l e s o f c a r b o n a t o m s p e r m o l e o f g l y c e r o l G l y c e r o l c o n v e r s i o n ( X ) a t t i m e t = I n i t i a l g l y c e r o l m o l e s − F i n a l g l y c e r o l m o l e s a t t i m e t I n i t i a l m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l 2.3 Characterization and analysis The as-obtained catalyst was crushed to sub-micron sizes, so that pore diffusion resistances are eliminated. With this and by choosing a sufficiently high RPM so as to eliminate external mass transfer resistances, one can be sure that the rate is governed by intrinsic kinetics. The particle size and morphology were studied using FEG-SEM (Make: JEOL; Model: JSM-7600F) and FEG-TEM (Make: FEI; Model: Tecnai G2, F30). BET method (Instrument: Micromeritics; Model: ASAP 2020) was used to find the surface area and pore size distribution. The sample chamber was evacuated to degas the sample before performing liquid nitrogen adsorption. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Make: Thermo Fisher Scientific Instruments; Model: K Alpha+) was used to analyse any changes in the oxidation state of the catalysts after the respective pre-treatments. The X-ray source used was Al K-α monochromatic beam with 6 mA and 12 kV. The instrument is calibrated with Ag 3d (352 eV). A spot size of 400 µm on the sample is irradiated. Binding energy (B.E.) charge correction was done using C-1s reference. Pd 3d core level B.E. is measured to compare the oxidation states of Pd in the differently treated catalysts. X-ray diffraction (XRD; Make: ThermoFisher Scientific; Model: Equinox 100) was used to characterize the differently treated catalysts and to get the signature of the Pd and PdO crystalline phases in the catalysts to support the XPS results. X-ray patterns were recorded using Cu Kα source (1.54 Å) in the 2θ range 10˚ to 100˚. To determine the concentration of active metal sites, CO pulse chemisorption was performed in the TPDRO instrument. Pure CO gas was connected to the instrument, and 10 pulses of a known volume were automatically injected at intervals of 5 min with Helium as carrier gas at room temperature. A pre-calibrated thermal conductivity detector (TCD) helps to quantify the amount of CO at the exit in each pulse, from which, the concentration of active metal sites and percentage metal dispersion can be determined. Literature [9] discusses the uncertainties in the stoichiometry of CO chemisorption on Pd. Here, for purposes of comparison, the stoichiometric ratio of Pd to CO for chemisorption was taken to be 1.5. Because of the uncertainties mentioned, the number of active sites has also been calculated from average particle sizes of catalysts based on TEM images, and this has been used in calculation of metal dispersion and turnover frequencies (TOF). TOF is defined as the molecules of reactant (glycerol) converted per unit time per active site and one needs to know the value of metal dispersion in order to calculate this from (say) the initial rate of glycerol conversion. The dispersion may be determined from the metal particle size. The size distribution of metal particles as determined by TEM (see Figure S-2 in the Supplementary material) was found to be rather broad and hence, rather than calculating the dispersion from an average size, it was calculated separately for different size slices and a weighted average taken (see Supplementary material for more details of the calculation procedure). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 TEM, SEM and BET Catalyst particle size and morphology were studied by electron microscopy. Particle size distribution obtained from TEM imaging (processed using image analysis software, ImageJ) and the corresponding images and formulae are given in Supplementary material (Figure S-2). The number average and volume-to-surface average particle sizes are shown in Table 1 . It is observed from the TEM images that as-obtained catalyst has Pd particle size between 2 nm and 5 nm; number average size and volume-to-surface average sizes were not calculated for an as-obtained catalyst due to the difficulties in interpreting the size distribution information (Figure S-2 in Supplementary material). On the other hand, for pre-treated catalysts, it can be seen from the particle size distribution (Figure S-2) that the (number-averaged) size ranges from 20 to 25 nm. The formulae for calculating number average and volume-to-surface average sizes are given in Supplementary material. The FEG-SEM image given in Figure S-2 (Supplementary material) shows that crushed catalysts (Pd/Al2O3) particles are less than 5 µm. It must be noted here that as-obtained catalysts were crushed before giving different pre-treatments. The differences in the particle sizes between as-obtained catalysts and pre-treated catalysts are attributed to sintering, and are discussed in the Supplementary Material. The BET surface area of as-obtained Pd/Al2O3 was found to be 274 m2/g with an average pore width of 3.89 nm, and a t-plot micropore volume of 4.239×10−3 cm3/g for Pd/Al2O3 particles. Since the micro-porosity of catalyst is negligible, the internal (pore) diffusion is not expected to limit the overall reaction rate. 3.1.2 TPR, TPO, and CO pulse chemisorption TPR profile of as-obtained Pd/Al2O3 is shown in Fig. 2 (a). Pd takes up H2 at low temperatures to form the hydride PdxHy and the negative peak observed initially is due to the evolution of hydrogen from Pd-β hydride [18,19]; desorption and decomposition occur between 65 °C and 80 °C, which is seen in the form of a strong negative peak showing hydrogen evolution. On the other hand, the change in the oxidation state from PdOx to Pd0 occurs between 340 °C and 360 °C, showing hydrogen consumption. TPO profile of as-obtained Pd/Al2O3 is shown in Fig. 2(b). The broad peak near 360 °C indicates oxygen consumption, and hence, the change in the oxidation state from Pd to PdOx. These TPR and TPO observations are in agreement with those seen by Namdeo et al. [9]. DSC profiles (see Figure S-1 in Supplementary material) are also in support of the results from TPR and TPO. Pulse chemisorption is the technique used for characterizing metal dispersion in the supported metal catalysts. However, in the case of Pd catalysts, the following issues must be kept in time. Hydrogen forms Pd-β-hydride at room temperature leading to the absorption of hydrogen in the bulk of Pd [20]. Hence, instead of H2 pulse chemisorption as usually carried out for Au and Pt-based catalysts, CO pulse chemisorption is preferred for Pd-based catalysts. While some studies have used CO for pulse chemisorption, the stoichiometry of CO on Pd is not unique, and depends on number of factors. We have therefore calculated the metal cluster sizes based on TEM. However, for purposes of comparison, we have also carried out CO pulse chemisorption since it can give the information on the nature of CO chemisorption in differently pre-treated catalysts. As seen in Table 1, the amount of CO gas adsorbed per unit mass of the catalyst is different for catalysts with different pre-treatments – it is the highest for reduced catalyst, and lowest for the oxidized form. In other words, the coverage of CO over Pd is better than that over PdO, which may be ascribed to the partial occupancy of O-atom over Pd in the form of PdO. However, as has been discussed in [9] (also see [21]), the stoichiometry of CO adsorption (ratio of Pd to CO) over Pd can be 1 or 2 depending whether it is by linear bonding or coordinated bridge-bonding. Gurrath et al. [21] mention that it is safe to assume a stoichiometry of 1 for Pd particles smaller than 5 nm; however, such an assumption may lead to an underestimation of dispersion for larger Pd particles. Therefore, we re-iterate that it may be preferable to calculate metal dispersion based on the average particle size obtained from TEM. Table 1 shows the values of percentage metal dispersion (and metal particle size) calculated from pulse chemisorption experiments assuming a stoichiometric ratio Pd/CO = 1.5, as well as dispersion values calculated using size information from TEM. It is seen that, for the reduced catalyst, there is a good correspondence between the moles of CO adsorbed and the moles of metal active sites calculated from TEM size, and hence an assumption of a stoichiometry of 1:1 can be justified for this case. In case of oxidized catalyst, however, the amount of CO adsorbed is very small and a Pd/CO stoichiometry, calculated by the same procedure, is much higher than unity (close to 6). Hinokuma et al. [15], found from IR spectroscopy that CO adsorption over oxidized Pd/CeO2 is negligible at 50 °C while thermally aged catalysts containing metallic Pd showed “strong adsorption bands assigned to linear and bridged CO species”. The as-obtained catalyst presumably contains multiple forms of Pd such as Pd and PdO (see XPS evidence presented in Section 3.1.3 below) and shows adsorption values of CO better than oxidized catalyst but lesser than reduced catalysts. For this case, the particle sizes were too small, and could not be determined reliably from TEM. However, in spite of the small size, CO adsorption is of the same order of magnitude as that of pre-treated catalysts (information on adsorption on inert gas pre-treated catalyst is presented in Table S-1 in Supplementary material). This is because Pd agglomerates and/or clusters form over the alumina support as seen in the TEM image (See Figure S-2 in the Supplementary material). The above discussion underlines the difficulties in calculating dispersion values from CO chemisorption for Pd catalysts, and we have therefore preferred to use the dispersion values calculated from TEM sizes for calculation of TOF values from rate data in the sequel. 3.1.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-Ray diffraction (XRD) Binding energies (B.E.) of Pd 3d5/2 core level were measured by XPS. Table 2 presents the XPS results of differently pre-treated Pd/Al2O3 catalysts. For Pd0 (zero valent Pd), B.E. is 335.3 eV. Pd can exist in multiple oxidation states in the form of PdO, PdO2 or PdO3 [22]. Oxidized catalysts show a positive shift in the binding energy of Pd 3d5/2 core level as seen in Table 2. XPS core level spectra of 336.6–337.0 eV corresponds to PdOx/Pd ([9] and NIST XPS Database Version 4.0 (2012)). As-obtained catalysts show the presence of both the phases – Pd0 and PdOx (as shown in Table 2). Moreover, it may be noted from the last row of the Table 2 that spent supported catalyst showed no change in Pd 3d core level B.E. values after performing glycerol oxidation under given condition over as-obtained Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. Hence, it can be concluded that the reaction conditions and products formed do not affect the oxidation state of Pd. Figure S-3 (Supplementary material) compares the deconvoluted binding energy plots for XPS of differently treated catalysts with their unsupported counterparts, and Table S-2 compares the corresponding B.E. values. Implications of catalyst pre-treatment as well as of the absence of support material on full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of XPS curves are described in the Supplementary material, for purposes of comparison. To support the results from XPS, XRD was performed for differently treated supported Pd catalysts. The XRD results showed the presence of Pd and PdO phases in reduced and oxidized catalysts, and are given in the Supplementary material (Figure S-4). 3.2 Reaction studies In this section, we will discuss the results of the glycerol oxidation reaction carried out over Pd supported over alumina subjected to different pretreatments as described in Section 2.1. Experiments were carried out also on unsupported Pd catalyst (99.9 % pure granules obtained from Alfa Aesar), but since the catalyst loading (Pd to Glycerol ratio) was much higher, these experiments had significant influence of external mass transfer. They have not therefore been compared with the supported catalysts here for reaction performance, but X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) of unsupported Pd granules are discussed in the Supplementary material for comparison purposes (See Table S-2 and Figure S-3). From the literature [23,24], it is observed that glycerol oxidation over supported Pd, Pt, or Au catalyst under alkaline conditions yields the C3 compounds – Glyceric acid (GA) and Tartronic acid (TA) from the oxidation of primary hydroxyl groups as major products. Zope et al. [10] concluded from their DFT studies that catalytic oxidation of alcohols in general, and glycerol in particular, is a solution-mediated as well as surface-mediated reaction when carried out in a highly alkaline aqueous medium, and that the activation energy for deprotonation of primary hydroxyl group of glycerol as well as C–H bond activation for aldehyde intermediate formation is lowered in the alkaline medium. Ide and Davis [25] in their review article explained the role of hydroxyl group in catalyzing the oxidation reaction. In our pulse chemisorption experiment, we found that oxygen does not adsorb on the catalyst surface. It is well-known from the literature as well [10], that oxygen plays only an indirect role by regenerating the hydroxide ions under alkaline reaction conditions. Hence, oxygen concentration over solid catalyst surface may not influence the rate of reaction compared to its concentration in liquid phase as determined by its solubility in liquid phase and the rate of gas-liquid mass transfer. Furthermore, the mechanism reported [16] suggests that Tartronic acid is directly formed by oxidation of Glyceric acid. The stability of tartronic acid to further oxidation was studied in earlier work [26], where experiments performed to oxidize Tartronic acid under conditions similar to that used in the current work showed no measurable conversion after 300 min. In the current work, GA & TA are the desired products. GLYCA, OA, FA and CO2 were the other products detected. These form by various series and parallel reactions, which lower the selectivity towards C3 products. Fig. 3 shows the conversion-time profiles with the different catalysts used in this work, and it is seen that the order of initial conversion rates over different catalysts is as-obtained > reduced > oxidized. It took about 90 min to reach nearly 100 % conversion of GLY over as-obtained catalyst, while reduced and oxidized catalysts took 120 and 150 min, respectively. Fig. 4 shows that as-obtained and oxidized catalysts showed higher selectivity to C2 and C1 products – GLYCA, OA and FA. This can be explained from the mechanistic understanding given by Wang et al. [11] in their study on direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen molecules. They concluded that PdO(101) surface is more selective towards formation of H2O2 compared to Pd(111) surface. In the case of glycerol oxidation, Zope et al. [10] gave a mechanistic explanation for the fact that peroxide formation leads to C–C scission. Hence, by connecting these two results, it is possible to explain why selectivity to C–C scission products is higher over oxidized Pd surface and the as-obtained catalysts (which contain a certain amount of PdO phase, as verified by XPS analyses, see Table 2). On the other hand, from the study of Wang et al. [11], the presence of metallic Pd phase in reduced Pd catalyst and as-obtained Pd catalyst is active for peroxide decomposition, leading to hydroxide radical (HO*) formation which is required for the initial deprotonation step (as explained by Zope et al. [10] using DFT studies). Hence, the initial reaction rates are higher. Some studies were also carried out with inert gas pre-treated catalyst (with the same temperature program as used in the other pretreatments), and it was observed that in this case, while the conversion rates were comparable with as-obtained catalyst, the selectivity was in favor of C3 compounds, glycolic and formic acid yields being lower as compared to other pre-treated catalysts. Figure S-5 and Figure S-6 in Supplementary material show these results. Fig. 4 shows that in all the cases, CO2 forms from the very initial stages of the reaction itself, as evident from the carbon imbalance. However, since CO2 is calculated from mass balance, it carries the accumulated error from measurements of all other components. Also, it was observed (Fig. 4) in all the cases that the yield of C3 product – TA and C2 product – OA is monotonically increasing. This is attributed to the simultaneous secondary oxidation steps, i.e., oxidation of glyceric acid (GA) to tartronic acid (TA), and glycolic acid (GLYCA) to oxalic acid (OA). Conversely, a gradual monotonic decrease in yields of GA and GLYCA is seen because of the same reason. Among the different Pd catalysts studied here, as-obtained catalyst performed well in terms of rate. On the other hand, the reduced catalyst, as seen in Fig. 4, showed a higher yield of GA initially as well as lower CO2 formation. These results can be explained on the basis of studies on mechanism in the literature. Zope et al. [10], through their theoretical (DFT) and experimental (isotopic labelling) studies, implicated the intermediate H2O2 formation as the main reason for C–C scission reactions in the case of glycerol oxidation. According to their study, oxygen does not participate directly in the reaction, but rather assists indirectly in the regeneration of hydroxide radical (HO*) that acts as an electron scavenger. In the process, peroxide radical (HOO*) is formed which acts as a strong oxidizing agent, thereby causing C–C scission reactions, leading to GLYCA, OA, FA and CO2. Through DFT studies, they [10] explained the mechanism of alcohol oxidation in general, in aqueous alkaline medium over gold surface. Briefly, for the case of glycerol, the preferential deprotonation of primary hydroxyl groups in glycerol requires O–H bond activation, which is favoured in highly alkaline medium, resulting in glycerolate - an alkoxide intermediate. The adsorbed hydroxyl radical further activates C–H bond, and subsequently dehydrogenates to give an aldehydic intermediate. Next, it forms a geminal-diol, and further dehydrogenates to glyceric acid. Similarly, the other primary hydroxyl group deprotonates through O–H bond activation and is attacked by the adsorbed hydroxyl radical, subsequently, to give tartronic acid. The presence of noble metal catalysts like Pd, Pt and Au decreases the activation energy barrier for these steps. Wang et al. [11] in their study claim that the oxidation state of Pd affects the formation and decomposition of H2O2. Although their aim was to improve H2O2 yield, the result that demonstrates better decomposition rate of H2O2 is relevant to our study of glycerol oxidation. It must be noted that when reaction occurs between H2 and O2, H2O is also one of the favoured products, depending on the catalyst's surface state, and this happens in two ways: 1) the hydroperoxy intermediate (OOH*) decomposes to hydroxyl radical (HO*) and reacts with H-atom; 2) the hydrogen peroxide decomposes to two OH* to react with the dissociated H-atom. Through DFT studies, they described the interaction of O2 and H2 on Pd(111) and PdO(101) surfaces, and showed that the path leading to hydroperoxy intermediate, and subsequently, H2O2 formation is favoured over PdO(101) surface. Moreover, the energy barrier for decomposition of H2O2 is larger for PdO(101) than for Pd(111). In the case of glycerol oxidation, we can infer from Fig. 4 that oxidized Pd/Al2O3 leads to excessive formation of peroxide species, thus promoting C–C scission reactions, and hence, C2 and C1 compounds. A similar explanation is possible for the product profiles in case of as-obtained catalyst (which contains some amount of oxidized Pd phase). Conversely, the reduced catalyst showed a higher selectivity to GA throughout the reaction, compared to oxidized catalysts. However, the selectivity to C2 compound (GLYCA) and C1 compound (FA) is also found to be higher. These two products possibly form together in the same reaction step, as the trend suggests, although some additional formic acid could also form directly from glycerol (see Section 3.3.1 below). This may be attributed to the high rate of formation of short-lived intermediate aldehydic species that is more prone to C–C cleavage under strong oxidizing conditions. Furthermore, a critical look at the results also leads to the inference that oxidized and as-obtained catalysts gave relatively larger amount of secondary oxidation products like TA and OA, which are formed from GA and GLYCA, respectively. This is in line with the above-discussed explanation by Wang et al. [11] regarding a higher H2O2 decomposition energy barrier over PdO(101), thereby resulting in oxidation of primary oxidation products – GA and GLYCA. In the case of reduced catalysts, the results are quite encouraging as far as C3 selectivity is concerned, especially, for GA. Also, the selectivity to secondary oxidation products – TA and OA is much lesser than the other catalysts studied. Activities of the catalysts subjected to different pre-treatments are compared in terms of turn over frequencies (TOF) in Table 3 . TOFs are calculated from the initial glycerol conversion rates and the active metal site concentration obtained from TEM particle size distribution, as described in Section 2.3. Unlike the pre-treated catalysts, TOF for the as-obtained catalyst is reported assuming the single particle size of 5 nm, and not based on size distribution. If the full particle size distribution information were to be available, the TOF for the as-obtained catalyst would probably be smaller than this reported one. Table 3 shows that the TOF for the pre-treated Pd/Al2O3 catalysts are better than that for as-obtained catalyst although the initial rate is higher for as-obtained catalyst (as seen in Fig. 3). One of the reasons for this is the fact that Pd particle sizes are in 2–5 nm range for as-obtained catalyst compared to the pre-treated catalysts where Pd sizes are found to be typically between 20 and 25 nm. Thus, TOF gives a realistic estimate of catalytic activity. The difference between TOF of reduced and that of oxidized catalysts is not significant; however, the differences in selectivity to C3 compounds are significant. Among pre-treated catalysts including inert gas pre-treatment, the TOF values were found to be in the order: inert gas pre-treated > reduced ≈ oxidized (See also Table S-3 in Supplementary material). 3.3 Reaction pathways and kinetic modeling 3.3.1 Kinetic pathways and reaction extents It was proposed in our earlier work [17,26] that tartronic acid forms as a secondary oxidation product from glyceric acid, and oxalic acid from glycolic acid, as shown in Fig. 5 (left). Moreover, the pathway also proposes the formation of FA as a by-product of GLYCA formation. In such a case, the sum of moles of GLYCA and OA should be nearly equal to the moles of FA formed. However, an examination of the results in Section 3.2 shows that in this work, the moles of FA formed is much higher than the GLYCA+OA moles, and that too right from the initial phase of reaction, suggesting that FA forms by an additional pathway as well. Hence, the reaction network is modified as shown on the right in Fig. 5. Indeed, there is also some support in the literature for this [27–29]. While the effect of the different pretreatments on the reaction system would show up as differences in concentration profiles of the various participating species, it may be more instructive to focus on the reactions directly rather than on the species. An analysis based on the rates of individual reactions might serve us better in this respect. Such an analysis would consider the effect of pretreatments on the variation with time of the extents of the individual reactions in the system, and is developed below. The proposed reaction scheme based on Fig. 5 (right) comprises of six reactions among nine species, as given below: C3H8O3 + O2 → C3H6O4 + H2O (Reaction 1) C3H8O3 + 1.5O2 → C2H4O3 + HCOOH + H2O (Reaction 2) C3H8O3 + 3.5O2 → 3CO2 + 4H2O (Reaction 3) C3H8O3 + 2.5O2 → 2HCOOH + CO2 + 2H2O (Reaction 4) C3H6O4 + O2 → C3H4O5 + H2O (Reaction 5) C2H4O3 + O2 → (COOH)2 + H2O (Reaction 6) These reaction network can be represented in the matrix form as: where N is the stoichiometric matrix and a is the symbolic vector of species. The component mole balances as a function of reaction extents can be expressed, for a batch system, as (1) n − n 0 = N T ξ where n and n 0 are the column vectors of mole numbers (at any time and initial respectively), of length equal to the number of chemical species; ξ is the column vector of reaction extents (in moles) of length equal to the number of reactions. While ours is not, strictly speaking, a batch system because of continuous addition of oxygen to maintain constant pressure, the representation is still useful if we leave oxygen out of the species vector and the stoichiometric matrix in writing Eq-1. In this case, N will be of dimension 6 × 8 and a , n and n 0 , column vectors of length 8. For our reaction system then, the (truncated) stoichiometric matrix (N) may be partitioned into a 6 × 6 square matrix, N1 (grey-shaded square in the representation above) – care being taken to see that the columns chosen for inclusion in N1 are linearly independent – and a 6 × 2 rectangular matrix, N2 . With this partitioning, we may rewrite the mole balances as: (2) [ n ( 1 ) − n 0 ( 1 ) n ( 2 ) − n 0 ( 2 ) ] = [ N 1 T ξ N 2 T ξ ] Here, n ( 1 ) , n 0 ( 1 ) are vectors of length 6 and contain the mole numbers of the top 6 species (all linearly independent) in a , and n ( 2 ) , n 0 ( 2 ) are vectors of length 2 containing the mole numbers of CO2 and H2O. The upper part of this equation allows a calculation of reaction extents from the measured values of concentration changes of the chosen (independent) species, equal in number to the number of independent reactions, thus shifting the focus from species to reactions. Clearly, matrix N 1 T is non-singular, and the extent of reaction vector ( ξ ) can be calculated from the first row of Eq-2 as (3) ξ = ( N 1 T ) − 1 [ n ( 1 ) − n 0 ( 1 ) ] The variation of extents of reaction (in moles) calculated from Eq-3 with time can then be used to understand the effect of catalyst pre-treatment on the individual reactions in the network. In Fig. 6 , reaction extents ( ξ i ) have been calculated from the measured concentrations of the top six species GLY to OA in the species vector for different reaction times, allowing us to compare the effect of the treatments given to Pd/Alumina catalysts on the course of individual reactions in the network. It can be seen that, the extents of reactions 1–4 that glycerol enters into as a reactant, are higher for the as-obtained catalyst (as compared to catalysts which have received different pretreatments). The extents of secondary oxidation reactions ((Reaction 5 and Reaction 6) are also significantly higher for as-obtained catalyst. This has consequences on the yield-conversion profiles as seen in Fig. 4. For example, the as-obtained catalyst being more selective to reactions 3 and 4 which form CO2 directly from glycerol results in a higher rate of formation of CO2 with this catalyst from the start. The higher overall rate of consumption of glycerol with the as-obtained catalyst is also easy to understand from the higher rates of all glycerol consuming reactions for the as-obtained catalyst. Similarly, the yield of secondary oxidation products (TA and OA) being significantly higher for as-obtained catalyst, is a consequence of the reaction extent for reaction 5 and 6 being significantly higher than for pre-treated catalysts. The effect of pretreatments on the concentration profiles of intermediates such as Glyceric acid and glycolic acid has to be understood from how their formation and consumption reactions are influenced by the pretreatments. Although the magnitude of reaction extents is small for Reaction 4 irrespective of the catalyst, the rate of additional formic acid formation from Reaction 4 seems to be much higher in case of reduced and as-obtained catalysts as compared to oxidized catalysts, which would be difficult to see if not for the reaction-extent based analysis. An additional advantage of tracking extents of reactions as functions of time (over the conventional method of tracking only concentrations) is that it helps us to identify erroneous data sets. For example, in the case discussed above (Fig. 6), it was found that the calculated extent of reaction 4 initially increased and then decreased at higher conversions (also see Figure S-7 in the Supplementary material). Since extents should either increase or become constant, this behaviour suggests a problem with the late conversion data set. Thus, for kinetic modelling and parameter fitting in the sequel, the data points showing decrease in reaction extent with time were eliminated from consideration. 3.3.2 Kinetic modeling based on extents of reaction Reaction data obtained under kinetic control, with catalysts subjected to different pretreatments, were used for kinetic analysis. Conventionally, a proposed kinetic model is fitted to concentration-time data in order to estimate the model parameters. For this purpose, the set of differential equations governing the concentrations of different species in a batch reactor are written as: d C j d t = ∑ ϑ i j r i , j = 1 , 2 , … 8 where r i stands for the rate of ith reaction and ϑ i j represents the stoichiometric coefficient of jth species in the ith reaction (positive for product species and negative for reactant species) [26]. However, in this work, we perform parameter estimation using the extents of reaction calculated from concentration data. In terms of reaction extents, the reactor mole balances transform as (for a batch reactor): d ξ i d t = V × r i , i = 1 , 2 , … , 6 Here, r i is the rate of ith reaction (Unit [=] mol/L/min), V is the batch volume (Unit [=] liter), and ξ i is the extent of ith reaction (Unit [=] moles). As in the earlier analysis, this formulation keeps the focus on the reactions rather than on the chemical species. For reactions 1 to 6, we try simple first order (in the reactant) rate equations r i as following. r 1 = k 1 C 1 r 2 = k 2 C 1 r 3 = k 3 C 1 r 4 = k 4 C 1 r 5 = k 5 C 2 r 6 = k 6 C 4 The concentration of j th species is calculated as C j = n j V (Unit [=] mol/L) where n j is the number of moles of j th species (corresponding to species vector a discussed in Section 3.3.1), expressed in terms of the extents from Eq-3 modified as below. (4) [ n ( 1 ) ] = [ N 1 T ξ ] + n 0 ( 1 ) In the above formulation the rate constants are (in general) functions of the oxygen concentration, which is constant since the oxygen pressure is kept constant throughout the reaction and the liquid is assumed to be saturated with oxygen due to the choice of reaction conditions which ensure kinetic control. In our earlier work [26], Langmuir-Hinshelwood type of rate equations were used to model the kinetics. Here however, we found that a simpler formulation of the type above fitted the reaction data equally as well as the more complex Langmuir-Hinshelwood forms, and hence have preferred the simpler formulation above. Further, because of the highly alkaline conditions employed, all the acid products are assumed to be in completely dissociated form. To estimate the rate parameters, the above differential equations in terms of extents of reaction were numerically integrated using MATLAB's subroutine ode45 with assumed initial guesses for the rate parameters. The latter are then refined by comparing the estimated reaction extents ( ξ i , e s t ) with the experimental reaction extents ( ξ i , e x p ) , and minimizing the relative residual sum of squares (also known as relative sum of squared errors), given below, using subroutine lsqnonlin. R S S = ∑ i = 1 R ( ξ i , e x p − ξ i , e s t ξ i , e x p ) 2 Here, R is the total number of reactions (six in this case) according to the proposed kinetic pathway. A typical fit of the model (for the case of reduced Pd/Al2O3 catalyst) to reaction extents calculated from the data is demonstrated in Figure S-8 in the Supplementary material, while model comparisons with concentration-time data will be discussed in the further paragraphs. Table 4 shows the estimated rate parameters from the model fitting for the differently treated catalysts studied here. The values within the parenthesis are the 95 % confidence bounds on the estimates, calculated using the method of F-statistic as described in our earlier work [26], also found in the literature [30,31]. Briefly, the variance ratio obtained by individually perturbing the rate parameters from its optimum value is compared with the critical F-value to get the confidence bounds. The figures below (Figs. 7–9 ) show the corresponding concentration-time profiles, and Table 5 shows the correlation coefficients for the fitted concentration-time profiles. From the parameter estimates, it is seen that all reaction rate constants are significantly higher for as-obtained catalyst as compared to the pre-treated ones. Among pre-treated catalysts, the differences in rate parameters of reactions 5 and 6, giving secondary products – TA and OA, are quite marginal. Here, the 95 % confidence bounds on the estimates (as given in the parenthesis in Table 4) indicate that the objective function (RSS above) is more sensitive to some of the parameter estimates as compared to others. For example, the larger bounds in case of parameters k5 and k6 shows that even a fairly large deviation in their values affects the RSS only slightly. However, since the estimates k5 and k6 are for the secondary oxidation products, the confidence bounds may also broaden due to the effect of errors in primary oxidation products. Reactions 3 and 4 (which contain k3 and k4) form CO2, the mole numbers of which is not measured but calculated from mass balance, resulting in accumulation of errors from other components; thus, the larger bounds on these parameters would also be partly due to errors. 3.3.3 Statistical analyses of the model Parametric sensitivity analysis is carried out as described in our earlier published article [26]. Briefly, the sensitivity of the relative sum of squared errors (RSS) is captured by changing the rate parameters one at a time, keeping the others at their optimum values. From the plot (given as Figure S-9 in Supplementary material), it can be inferred that the system behaviour is more sensitive to the rate parameters k1 and k2, for the reactions leading to glyceric and glycolic acids (i.e., Reaction 1 & 2) as compared to the others. The parity plot of experimental concentration values versus simulated concentration values at the optimum rate parameters (Fig. 10 ) shows that the kinetic pathway and the corresponding model explain the experimental observations well, to within ±20 %, for the given catalysts and reaction conditions. While using the kinetic model, one must make sure that the model should not be extrapolated to experimental conditions which are well outside the ones reported here. The residual plot (Fig. 11 ) indicates that, for the most part, the residual values are randomly scattered throughout the concentration range and is not correlated with concentration values for any given concentration range or for any given catalyst. 4 Conclusions This study has been concerned with the effect of oxidation state of the Pd metal in Pd/Al2O3 catalysts on the activity and selectivity in the alkaline oxidation of glycerol, and along the way, introduced certain novel methods of data analysis and parameter estimation in kinetic studies. The oxidation state of Pd metal was varied via different pretreatments given to the catalyst. XPS was used to determine the change in the oxidation state of Pd. It is shown that the effect of pretreatments can be assessed by postulating a reaction network with literature support, and studying how individual reactions in the network are influenced, by transforming the concentration-time information to reaction extents. The data on glycerol oxidation showed that C3 selectivity and TOF was better and C–C scission reaction leading to formic acid and CO2 lower, in the case of reduced catalyst. Comparing the yield-conversion profiles, C3 selectivity was much better in the case of reduced catalyst as compared to as-obtained as well as oxidized catalyst. The above experimental findings have been rationalized on the basis of how pretreatments affect individual reactions in the network. The analysis shows that oxidation of glyceric acid to tartronic acid (Reaction 5) and oxidation of glycolic acid to oxalic acid (Reaction 6) are most influenced by the pretreatment received by the catalysts, and the others, to a much lesser extent. Additionally, the difference between oxidized and reduced catalyst is observed in case of Reaction 4 (i.e., glycerol oxidation to two moles of formic acid and one mole of CO2). These findings can form the basis for more detailed theoretical and experimental studies on reaction mechanisms in this complex reaction network. coredata.dc:description: Oxidation state of the catalyst is important in determining the activity and selectivity of the catalyst in complex reaction networks. This effect is investigated here in the context of glycerol oxidation. An attempt is made to understand the effect of catalyst pre-treatment (oxidative and reductive) on Pd/Alumina for glycerol oxidation, and correlate the reaction performance with the oxidation state of Pd. Characterisation techniques such as XPS, TEM, CO pulse chemisorption have been used to understand the effect of pre-treatment on the oxidation state of the metal. The reduced catalyst was found to be more selective to C3 compounds than the oxidized catalyst. It is suggested that this difference in selectivity is due to differences in hydrogen peroxide formation over Pd and PdO phases, because of the role of peroxide in bringing about C–C scission. A novel procedure for parameter estimation based on reaction extents has been used to delineate the effect of pre-treatments on different reactions in the network. The results have been supported by systematic statistical analyses.
